subject: RE: [junit] JUnit or JTest ?

messageBody:
My experience with JTest comes from speaking with the JTest engineers and
seeing some demos, so please view the following comments in that light.

JTest has two aspects:
1) Coding standards review
2) Locating unhandled exceptions.

The first aspect is definitely interesting, but is also provided by a number
of less expensive tools. I don't know whether they are all equivalent
regarding completeness.

The second aspect is the one is where the most confusion between JTest,
JUnit and our tool, Test Mentor come in. JTest examines your code a class at
a time and derives a set of inputs that will drive code paths for those
classes, for the purpose of detecting unhandled exceptions. The scheme it
uses does not naturally find logic errors. You need to write tests for this,
although you can capture simple inputs and outputs as 'regression' tests.
This is certainly useful, but you're not going to find very many logic
errors this way without a lot of work, and validation is fairly primitive.

The biggest weak points for JTest are:
1) JTest does not actually execute code in a Java virtual machine. According
to the Parasoft engineer that I spoke with, JTest simulates execution, but
you are not really running your code on any particular Java platform.
2) JTest tests are very class centric and do not scale up to clusters for
frameworks. This means that it will be difficult for your to test a class in
the context of other collaborating classes.
3) JTest is rather expensive (around $3500?).
4) JTest is very slow. In all fairness it is doing a tremendous amount of
computation in parsing code and simulating execution, but it's not something
you'd be able to run every few minutes - more like overnight.
5) It takes a while to crawl through the output that JTest creates. There
are usually quite a number of false positives and you have to do a bit of
manual work to figure out which output indicates real problems, or spend
some time configuring the tool to ignore certain conditions.

If you have the money, you might want to consider purchasing a single
license to run periodically overnight on a lab machine. If you're already
doing a good job writing real tests with JUnit or a commercial tool like
Test Mentor, it will probably be redundant.

If you are at the end of a cycle and have no time or intention to write
tests, you might consider using JTest to do a massive sweep of your code.
It's bound to find something interesting. Just be careful that if you use
JTest to find problems and then start fixing them, you may introduce new
logic problems in your code that JTest does not find.
